question_text: In a case scenario of POEMS syndrome, what will you find in the serum?

options.A: Anti-GM1
patient presents with flaccid weakness. What is a possible cause?
patient on statin therapy develops necrotizing myositis. What is the most likely cause?
female patient complains of hand numbness that wakes her from sleep and improves with shaking her hand. What is the likely diagnosis?

male patient presented to the outpatient clinic for evaluation of limb weakness. He has upper limb weakness that started 6 years ago, initially affecting the right hand and progressively involving all three limbs. On physical examination, he has muscle atrophy, absent triceps reflex, and intact brachioradialis reflex. Sensory examination was normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

patient post hip replacement surgery presents with right lower limb weakness. Examination showed hip flexion and extension 5/5, foot dorsal flexion 0/5, plantarflexion 3/5 with sensory loss of the lateral leg. EMG/NCS showed involvement of the anterior tibial, gastrocnemius, and short head of biceps femoris. What is the most likely injured nerve?

50-year-old male patient is complaining of chronic progressive bilateral ptosis associated with difficulty swallowing and difficulty speaking. On physical examination, he has mild weakness over shoulder and pelvic muscles bilaterally. Muscle biopsy shows internuclear tubular filaments. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
patient with typical features of myasthenia gravis has negative ACHR antibody and Anti-MUSK tests. What lab investigation should be sent next to confirm the diagnosis?

male patient presented with symptoms suggestive of proximal muscle weakness. He has two cousins with the same presentation. EMG showed prolonged motor unit action potentials (MUAPs). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question_text: In a patient with median nerve conduction studies (NCS) at the elbow and wrist, what is the likely finding?

options.A: Conduction block
patient with Limb-Girdle Muscular Dystrophy (LGMD) and a positive family history is likely to have which of the following conditions?

question_text: In a case of acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (AIDP) with prior diarrhea 4 weeks ago, what type is indicated if only motor function is affected with intact sensory function?

options.A: Acute motor axonal neuropathy (AMAN)

question_text: Which muscle is tested in L5 EMG testing?

options.A: Tibialis anterior

question_text: In a case of Dermatomyositis, which of the following findings is typically observed?

options.A: Perifascicular atrophy
case of Facioscapulohumeral muscular dystrophy is presented. What is the likely diagnosis?

question_text: Paramyotonia is associated with which type of channel?

options.A: Sodium Channel (SCN4A)

question_text: What is a potential early complication of Guillain-Barré syndrome?

options.A: Choking
young female came with dilated pupils, dysphagia, and descending weakness; what is the diagnosis?

question_text: Which of the following is a treatment option for Guillain-Barré syndrome?

options.A: Plasma exchange

question_text: The chromosome associated with the genetic basis of Hyperkalemic Periodic Paralysis is:

options.A: patient presents with weak facial muscles (cannot blow air) and weakness in the arm flexors and extensors, along with right foot drop and winging of the scapula. What is the most likely diagnosis?
patient came with a history of multifocal neuropathy multiplex. A biopsy showed necrosis and inflammatory cells in the vessels. What is the diagnosis?

patient presents with urinary incontinence and symptoms suggesting autonomic dysfunction along with painful neuropathy. Nerve conduction studies indicate axonal neuropathy with carpal tunnel syndrome. What is the most appropriate investigation?

question_text: In a case of inclusion body myositis (IBM), what are the histology findings?

options.A: Rimmed vacuoles
child presented with proximal muscle weakness and was diagnosed with laminopathy (or LMNA mutation) based on genetic testing. What is expected to be seen in examination?
